author: Anonym
title: Hate speech and slogans: more anti-Semitic crimes again - The Limited Times
text:
Status: 29.12.2023, 07:21 a.m.
CommentsPrint Share
A surveillance camera hangs on a faÃ§ade. Â© Marijan Murat/dpa
Hostilities against Jews continue to be part of everyday life in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg. And it turns out that the decreasing violence is on the rise again after a brief decline. Not all deeds go to German accounts.
Stuttgart - There is agitation and insults, Israeli flags are burned and walls are smeared with slogans. And that almost every day somewhere in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg. In the first nine months of this year alone, 184 anti-Semitic crimes were registered, which is slightly more than in the first three quarters of the previous year (175). And the number is likely to rise significantly, because the protests following the massacre by the Islamist Hamas in Israel on October 7 are not yet included in the statistics. There is an increase in anti-Semitic crimes in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg, the Ministry of the Interior said on request.
A brief look back shows this: In mid-November, the Bundesliga football club VfB Stuttgart banned two spectators from the stadium for racist and anti-Semitic insults. A few days earlier, anti-Semitic paint smears were discovered at the WÃ¼rttembergische LandesbÃ¼hne in Esslingen and on steps leading to the castle there, unknown persons also smeared the back of Rastatt Castle with slogans in red spray paint, and house walls in Ludwigsburg were also sprayed. In the three weeks after the Hamas attack alone, around 30 crimes related to Israeli flags were registered, according to the State Office of Criminal Investigation.
"The Jews' sense of security has been permanently shaken," said Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg Interior Minister Thomas Strobl (CDU) against the background of the war against Hamas and the demonstrations against Israel. "It is intolerable that Jewish people are now hesitant again or do not dare to identify themselves as Jews on our streets." Physical assaults and direct confrontations are the absolute exception in the southwest. "But any destruction and damage to Israeli flags is also unacceptable. Because this also shows the evil grimace of anti-Semitism," said Strobl.
According to Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg's anti-Semitism commissioner Michael Blume, Hamas is also using the latest ways to exert influence: "Hamas has managed to use digital terror propaganda against Israelis to bring even more anti-Semites to the point of committing crimes," the doctor of religion and political science told the German Press Agency.
According to Blume, the number of anti-Semitic crimes in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg has increased by 206 percent in the past ten years. "However, the longer-term development of anti-Semitic crimes is a cause for concern both in the state and nationwide," Blume warns in his report to the state parliament, which has already been presented. "Anti-Semitism is an experience that many Jews regularly encounter in their everyday lives from the middle of society."
While the number of anti-Semitic crimes in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg was 2017 cases in 99, it increased to 136 a year later and finally to 182 in 2019 and 228 cases in 2020. Two years ago, it suddenly increased to 337, and a year later, after a significant decline, the number of crimes reached 245. And the police do not always see a political motive, it is not always clear what is behind it.
The catalogue of anti-Semitic offences includes incitement to hatred as well as insults or the so-called use of signs of unconstitutional organisations, usually the wearing of a swastika. According to the Ministry of the Interior, the focus in the past year was on the damage or removal of flags of the State of Israel, which were hoisted at town halls, for example, as a sign of solidarity. Damage to property in the form of paint smears, some of which incited hatred, also belonged to this area. "Physical assaults and direct confrontations remain rare," the Interior Ministry said.
According to these data, the majority of anti-Semitic crimes are still motivated by right-wing extremism, with a clear upward trend. Of the 184 violent crimes in the first nine months of this year, 135 are attributed to this so-called phenomenon area, compared to 109 cases in the first three quarters of the previous year.
My news Lake in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg is the largest in the country â€“ it is often overlookedread
The oldest butcher's shop in Germany comes from Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg read
These outlet centers in Baden-Wurttemberg areRead more
Mother to blame for the death of child (2) from Bingen? Lawyer with emotional plea: "This is the biggest punishment"read
The largest mineral water deposit in Germany has a town in Baden-WÃ¼rttembergread
Small town in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg is the most popular holiday resort in Germanyread
Just a few days ago, the president of the Federal Criminal Police Office had also complained about a drastic increase in anti-Semitic crimes nationwide. "The dimension in the area of these crimes is new," Holger MÃ¼nch told the "Neue ZÃ¼rcher Zeitung" (Tuesday). Anti-Semitism has increased on both the left and the right, but it is also imported. "Many people have come to our country from regions where Israel is considered an enemy and where there is a perception that Jews must be fought," MÃ¼nch said. This anti-Semitism, imported from abroad, must be named and action must be taken against it. Dpa

author: Sophie Knight The Daily
title: UWâ€™s role in the perpetual occupation of Palestine
text:
Around this time last year, I wrote an article about
the student-led effort of Resist US-Led War Seattle to cut UWâ€™s ties with Boeing. The companyâ€™s long-standing influence on UW and enablement of the military pursuits of our government has driven this organization into action.
Resist is a national organization seeking to dismantle imperialism and militarism led by the United States. In Seattle, the local chapterâ€™s work primarily focuses on political education and mobilization of those in the Seattle area â€” especially college students.
The organization shifted gears Oct. 7, when Hamas militants attacked an Israeli city. It provided an opportunity to alert locals on the impact of UWâ€™s partnership with Boeing in the Israeli occupation of Palestine.
Boeing is a major supplier to the Department of Defense, and the U.S. government is a major supplier of arms to Israel.
Just last year, Boeing signed a
$927 million deal with Israel to supply the military with four KC-46A aerial refuelers. Quickly after the initial retaliations against Hamas, Boeing delivered over 1,000 bombs to the Israeli military in their airstrikes in the Gaza Strip.
â€œYou canâ€™t separate UW from Boeing,â€ Zho Ragen, a Ph.D. student and member of Resist US-Led War Seattle, said.
Boeing has been a significant investor in UW since 1917. Along with funding research facilities on campus, the local company recruits a large number of engineering students. As of 2022, roughly 1,200 UW alumni were hired by Boeing in the last five years, and 6,500 alumni are currently working for the company.
But do these present and future employees fully grasp the scope of Boeingâ€™s involvement in the upkeep of war?
Nikhil, a UW employee, expressed that he believes students have been misled by mass media institutions and the public education system.
â€œMore and more, students are experiencing exploitation,â€ Nikhil said. â€œThey are learning how to dismantle a system that doesnâ€™t serve peoplesâ€™ needs.â€
Resist Seattle has contributed to this through both their protests and teach-ins.
At UW, Resist has led several protests and walk-outs on and around campus, one of them being at the Boeing Military Delivery Center in November of 2023. Along with this action, they prioritize teach-ins, seeking political education. Most recently,
â€œFrom Palestine to Hawaiâ€™i: Resist the U.S. War Machineâ€ on Jan. 24 and 25 informed students on issues regarding current U.S. military strategy.
These teach-ins seek to explain many of the complex factors of the U.S. power: the role of educational institutions, the current foreign strategy of the Biden administration, and the basis of imperialism.
â€œWe have power when weâ€™re united and exposing the system,â€ Nikhil said.
Historically, major protests that have led to a change in policy were the result of various marginalized groups acting in solidarity. In the â€˜60s and â€˜70s, for example, the mass protests incited by anti-war student organizations imposed pressure on the Nixon administration to eventually end the Vietnam War.
Theyâ€™ve collaborated with student organizations like Students United for Palestinian Equality & Return (SUPER) UW, the Black Student Union (BSU), and Anakbayan UW, among many others. More recently, there is a coalition of student organizations called UW United Front working to get UW to cut ties with Boeing and Israel.
â€œThis is becoming a very strong and bolstering cause for grassroots organizations,â€ Ragen said. â€œItâ€™s helping people raise their political consciousness and recognize all of these problems are very interconnected.â€
Why should college students care about these complex ideas and global events?
â€œYou donâ€™t need to know much to know this isnâ€™t okay,â€ Ragen said.
Simply taking in what is going on every day can say a lot about the situation. Understanding the history is one thing, but seeing how our tuition, taxes, government, and our school is actively contributing to the occupation is alarming in and of itself.
â€œThe university is facilitating the needs of corporations and fascist governments and U.S. imperialism instead of the needs of students,â€ Nikhil said.
Once people grasp that our struggles as Americans and as students at UW are connected to the external offenses of our own government, the conflicts overseas become much more straightforward. The global economic interests of the U.S. have and will continue to upstage the domestic concerns of its citizens.
â€œWe want to meet the calls and needs of students for livelihood and international solidarity with peoplesâ€™ struggles against imperialism,â€ Nikhil said.
Ragen explained that the result of this system will always be war and militarism. Consequently, people will resist, and the U.S. will utilize its force to maintain the system â€” which is what weâ€™re seeing in Gaza now.
Thereâ€™s a lot of history at play in Gaza, much of which the West had a massive role in forming.
What weâ€™re seeing now is a reflection of this occupation, as Palestinians living under the control of the Israeli government are being killed and displaced to make way for Israeli settlers.
The U.S. didnâ€™t always support Israel, but the late 1960s changed that, as fears of alliances between Arab nations and the Soviet Union rose. Now, we can see the unwavering military support of Israel under the Biden administration.
Now, with the death toll in Gaza reaching over 26,000 people â€“ an unprecedented amount in the 75-year conflict â€” organizations like Resist and other student groups are exposing the imperial roots of corporations and the U.S. governmentâ€™s involvement in the perpetuation of violence against Palestinians.
The deep connections among these institutions are intimidating, but it also means they rely on each other to maintain the system. By bringing attention to UWâ€™s partnership with Boeing and demanding divestment, students can weaken Boeingâ€™s influence domestically and globally.
Reach writer Sophie Knight at X: @knightsophie13

here.

å…‰æŽ§é»é™„çš„â€œæŸ”æ€§é©å‘½â€

author: Times of Oman
title: Hazlewood's pace combined with Head's blitz seal dominant 10-wicket victory for Australia in 1st Test against West Indies
text:
Adelaide: Josh Hazlewood's career-best haul of 9-79 in red-ball cricket guided Australia to a thumping 10-wicket victory in the first Test against West Indies on Friday at the Adelaide Oval.
Australia's clinical performance saw Hazlewood scalping nine and Head scoring a rollicking ton in a Test that lasted just more than two days. Hazlewood with a bit of movement from the pitch blew away West Indies' batting line-up while Head's aggressive strokes kept the opposition bowling line-up at bay.
The Caribbean side resumed the day with a score of 73/6 trailing by 22 runs. Mitchell Starc and Josh Hazlewood in the first six overs combined to bag three wickets, putting the visitors under pressure.
Shamar Joseph came at the end and showed his skills with the bat by finding the boundary line thrice with composure. He looked poised to play a couple of more shots, but Nathan Lyon's spin got the better of the 24-year-old.
West Indies managed to put up 120 on the board leaving the hosts a paltry target of 26.
Steve Smith and Usman Khawaja stepped on the crease, looking to quickly put West Indies out of their misery. Joseph who impressed in the first innings by dismissing Smith on the first ball of his Test debut was denied the opportunity to bowl with the new ball.
His time to bowl came in the fifth over when Australia needed 14 to walk away with victory. In the 7th over, the awkward bounce took Khawaja by surprise and the ball struck him on his helmet as he tried to move out of the line.
He ended up retiring hurt with a score of 9, Marnus Labuschagne came in scored the winning runs and sent Australia one up in the series. Both teams will meet at Gabba on January 25.
Earlier in the Test, Australia reaped rewards from their decision to put West Indies to bat as they restricted the visitors to 188.
In reply, the Caribean side put Australia in a tough spot as they claimed five wickets while the hosts managed to put 129 runs on the board. Cummins and Hazlewood scalped four each to put Australia in control.
But Travis Head once again proved to be a game-changer for the hosts. His aggressive intent prevented the West Indies from fathoming their way out and making an unexpected return.
The visitors put Australia in a tough spot as they claimed five wickets while the hosts managed to put 129 runs on the board. Head on a tricky surface went all guns blazing and scored 119 off 134 deliveries which was laced with 12 boundaries and three maximums.
His knock propelled Australia to a score of 283 allowing them to gain a healthy lead of 95 runs. West Indies did walk back with some positives as debutant Shamar Joseph claimed a five-wicket haul. Along with him, Kemar Roach and Justin Greaves bagged two each.
Brief Score: West Indies 188 & 120 (Kirk McKenzie 26, Justin Greaves 24; Josh Hazlewood 5-35) vs Australia 283 & 26/0 (Steve Smith 11*, Usman Khawaja (retired hurt) 9).

author: Nicole Nixon - The Sacramento Bee (TNS)
title: Prop. 36 asks California voters to OK stricter punishments for repeat drug, theft offenders
text:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. â€” This November, Proposition 36 will ask California voters whether to undo a handful of criminal justice reforms they approved a decade ago.
In 2014, voters passed another ballot measure called Proposition 47, which reduced punishments for a handful of non-violent drug and theft crimes. Prop. 47 made most drug possession crimes a misdemeanor and raised the threshold for felony theft and forgery from $400 to $950.
This yearâ€™s Proposition 36 is pushed by a coalition of district attorneys from across the state, along with major retailers like Target and Walmart. Itâ€™s aimed at cracking down on retail theft and fentanyl, and supporters argue it would close gaps in the stateâ€™s sentencing rules to bring more accountability.
Videos of retail thefts â€“ from coordinated smash-and-grabs at designer stores to individuals stuffing items in backpacks at drugstores â€“ during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic threw a spotlight on the issue. And the emergence of the potent opioid fentanyl, which led to the deaths of around 6,000 Californians in 2021, has added new urgency to the drug crisis.
State lawmakers in Californiaâ€™s Democratic supermajority have wrestled with how to address the two issues without undoing the main tenets of Prop. 47, which was passed in part to reduce the population in the stateâ€™s overcrowded prisons.
Progressive Democrats in control of the Legislatureâ€™s public safety committees have, for the most part, refused to pass laws that would increase criminal penalties, citing a historically biased criminal justice system that has put disproportionately more Black and brown people behind bars.
Because of that, Prop. 36 has fractured the ranks of elected Democrats. Gov. Gavin Newsom, Assembly Speaker Robert Rivas, Senate President pro Tem Mike McGuire and other Democratic lawmakers oppose the ballot measure. But some moderate Democratic lawmakers and influential big-city mayors support it.
Newsom and legislative leaders were even planning a countermeasure earlier this summer, but they abandoned it at the eleventh-hour last month, just before lawmakers recessed for their summer recess.
What a â€˜yesâ€™ vote on Prop. 36 means
Prop. 36 contains several components related to criminal punishments. A yes vote would:
â€¢Increase punishment for certain drug and theft crimes. Currently, theft of property worth $950 or less is usually a misdemeanor. Prop. 36 would make it a felony for people who have two or more previous theft-related convictions on their record.
â€¢Create a new â€œtreatment-mandated felonyâ€ classification for drug crimes. If a person with two or more previous drug convictions is charged with possession of a substance â€” specifically, fentanyl, heroin, cocaine or methamphetamine â€” they could be ordered to get treatment. Those who finish treatment could have their charges dismissed; however, failure to complete treatment could result in a sentence of up to three years in prison.
â€¢Require courts to warn people convicted of selling or giving drugs to others that they could be charged with murder if they sell drugs that kill someone.
What a â€˜noâ€™ vote means
A no vote on Proposition 36 would keep criminal sentencing laws as they are: theft valued under $950 and drug possession crimes would continue to generally be prosecuted as misdemeanors, with a punishment of up to one year in jail.
Who supports Prop. 36?
Prop. 36 is supported by a broad swath of business and law enforcement groups, the California Republican Party and a smattering of Democratic elected officials.
The California Business Roundtable, California Sheriffs Association, California District Attorneys Association and the California Retailers Association are supporting the measure.
Mayors supporting Prop. 36 include Democrats London Breed of San Francisco, Todd Gloria of San Diego, Matt Mahan of San Jose and Bobbie Singh-Allen of Elk Grove.
â€œCalifornia is suffering from an explosion in crime and the trafficking of deadly hard drugs like fentanyl,â€ proponents wrote in official ballot arguments for the measure. â€œProp. 36 will fix the mess our politicians have ignored for far too long. It is a balanced approach that corrects loopholes in state law that criminals exploit to avoid accountability for fentanyl trafficking and repeat retail theft.â€
As of mid-August, the Yes campaign had raised more than $7.9 million. Top donors include major retailers like Walmart ($2.5 million), Target ($1 million) and Home Depot ($1 million).
Opponents of Prop. 36
While some Democrats are supporting Prop. 36, many others oppose it, including Newsom, lawmakers and some progressive DAs, including Diana Becton of Contra Costa County.
The initiative also faces opposition from criminal justice reform groups like the Anti-Recidivism Coalition and the Vera Institute of Justice.
â€œWe must address persistent problems like theft and fentanyl, but we must use solutions that work and are targeted at the actual issue, instead of the scattershot failed solutions of the past,â€ opponents wrote in the official ballot arguments
â€œBy making simple drug possession a felony, this measure will send thousands into state prison, drive up prison costs, and slash money for local safety programs. That will make crime worse, not better.â€
As of mid-August a ballot committee opposing Prop. 36 had raised $195,000, with sizeable donations from the ACLU of Northern California along with philanthropists Quinn Delaney and Stacy H. Schusterman.
Fiscal impacts of Prop. 36
If approved, Prop. 36 would likely increase state criminal justice costs by tens or hundreds of millions of dollars; counties could also pay tens of millions more, according to an analysis by the Legislative Analystâ€™s Office.
Thatâ€™s because harsher criminal punishments means people convicted of these crimes would spend more time in prison.
The LAO analysis predicts the state prison population, which is currently around 90,000, could grow by â€œa few thousand peopleâ€ under Prop. 36. Statewide, county jails could see a similar increase.
State court workloads would also increase since felonies take more time to resolve than misdemeanors.
Finally, by undoing parts of Prop. 47, the measure could mean less funding for mental health, drug treatment, and other prevention programs.
Â©2024 The Sacramento Bee. Visit at
sacbee.com. Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC.
